author: By J. David Goodman
title: Long Before Impeachment, G.O.P. Rifts Were Growing in Texas
description: The building conflict between moderates and hard-liners in one of the Republican Party’s most important states highlights tension over the future of the party.
content: The impeachment of the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, by a majority of his fellow Republicans has exposed an undercurrent of division and discontent that is roiling the Republican Party in the most populous state where it still enjoys near total political control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: At Least Three Are Killed in Clashes on Iranian-Afghan Border
description: The fighting comes amid rising political tension between the two countries over the flow of water from the Helmand River in Afghanistan into eastern Iran.
content: At least three people were killed and several others injured after clashes broke out along the Iranian-Afghan border on Saturday night, according to Iranian state media and an Afghan official, escalating tensions between the two countries amid a heated dispute over water rights in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Handshake Snub Gets a Chilly Reception at the French Open on Day 1
description: Marta Kostyuk of Ukraine had the crowd on her side initially, but then was booed after she did not shake hands with Aryna Sabalenka of Belarus after losing to her in straight sets.
content: The moment the women’s singles draw for the French Open pitted Aryna Sabalenka of Belarus against Marta Kostyuk of Ukraine in the opening round, there was no doubt the start of the tournament would produce some fireworks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: ​Tennessee Law Sows Fear Among Drag Performers Ahead of Pride Month
description: A judge is expected to rule as soon as this week on whether the new law banning “adult cabaret” in front of children is constitutional.
content: Renae Green-Bean had started taking precautions in public even before the Tennessee legislature approved a law in March limiting where “adult cabaret” can be performed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Despite Inflation, Earthquakes and Tough Race, Erdogan Is Re-elected
description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan has given few indications that he intends to change course at home, where he faces a looming economic crisis, or in foreign policy, where he has vexed Western allies.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan beat back the greatest political challenge of his career on Sunday, securing victory in a presidential runoff that granted five more years to a mercurial leader who has vexed his Western allies while tightening his grip on the Turkish state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Looks Like He Will Get the 2024 Crowd He Wants
description: Ron DeSantis entered the presidential race last week along with Tim Scott, with others to follow. For the former president, the more candidates the better.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida officially entered the presidential race last week, but he appears farther than ever from the one-on-one matchup that his allies believe he needs to wrest the nomination from former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Feinstein, Back in the Senate, Relies Heavily on Staff to Function
description: The California Democrat is surrounded by a large retinue of aides at all times, who tell her how and when to vote, explain what is going on when she is confused, and shield her from the press and public.
content: When Senator Dianne Feinstein entered a hearing room this month to reclaim her seat on the Senate Judiciary Committee after a monthslong absence, she was accompanied by a phalanx of aides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Miami Heat Are in Trouble, and It’s (Mostly) Their Fault
description: The Heat let a 3-0 series lead slip away in the Eastern Conference finals with sloppy play, bad shooting and disappearing acts by their stars.
content: After the miracle and the madness, Gabe Vincent broke the silence inside the Miami Heat locker room on Saturday night by humming along to “Life Goes On,” a ballad by Ed Sheeran featuring Luke Combs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: What’s in the Debt Deal
description: Leaders from both parties have reached an agreement.
content: America is a little closer to averting a self-imposed economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Even After Debunking, ‘Sybil’ Hasn’t Gone Away
description: The “true story” of a woman with multiple personalities was a 1973 sensation and is still in print 50 years later. Why do such lurid tales hold their grip?
content: Turning 50 is rarely easy for a woman, and “Sybil” is no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Josef Newgarden Wins Indianapolis 500
description: Newgarden, the two-time IndyCar series champion, won his first career Indy 500 after a late sprint. He passed last year’s winner, Marcus Ericsson, who disagreed with the restart procedure.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — The Indianapolis 500 is the one race Josef Newgarden desperately wanted to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Maitre d’ at Balthazar Spends His Sundays
description: As James Corden learned, you don’t want to end up in Zouheir Louhaichy’s shift report, which he writes in the morning before training for Ironman.
content: Zouheir Louhaichy, the head maître d’ at Balthazar, the perennially popular SoHo brasserie, doesn’t give just any customer his cell number. Those who have it, though, are not shy about reaching out on Sundays, his day off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Pursuit of Consensus, Did Biden Find the Reasonable Middle or Give Away Too Much?
description: The deal to raise the debt ceiling bolsters President Biden’s argument that he is committed to bipartisanship, but it comes at the cost of rankling many in his own party.
content: After weeks of tense wrangling between the White House and House Republicans, the fiscal deal reached on Saturday to raise the debt ceiling while constraining federal spending bolsters President Biden’s argument that he is the one figure who can still do bipartisanship in a profoundly partisan era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simi Horwitz
title: The Maestro’s Latest Opus: A Video Game to Save Classical Music
description: David Dubal, Renaissance man, aims to save the world of art with a game that teaches piano. First, he’ll have to get a computer.
content: In his velvet jacket, colorful scarf and longish, graying hair, David Dubal looks as if he might have emerged from a 19th-century daguerreotype album recalling the life and times of a lesser-known romantic poet, a Renaissance man from an era long gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Creamy, Spicy Poached Eggs for an Easy Sunday Morning
description: Tajín grilled chicken is a punchy cookout centerpiece, and a “big mess” pasta is a weeknight Roman romp.
content: Good morning. There’s no better breakfast than the one you make on the Sunday morning of a three-day weekend, at least if you’re not working. There’s nothing elegiac about the meal — it’s neither the first one you’ve cooked after a long week, nor the last one you’re making before getting back on the hamster wheel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living With the Loss of a Child: ‘I Feel Your Pain, Sarah Wildman’
description: Readers identify with Ms. Wildman’s “wrenching essay” about her young daughter’s death. Also: A child’s time to play and imagine; a woman’s anger.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Lange
title: Salt Life Is Coming to a Beach Near You
description: First, Salt Life was a tattoo. Then it became a logo. Now it is a lifestyle brand with plans to open stores from coast to coast.
content: On a blustery April morning in Long Branch, N.J, Lynn Mesler pointed to a Salt Life store that had opened six days before on Ocean Avenue North, across the street from the Atlantic Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: You’ve Never Heard of Him, but He’s Remaking the Pollution Fight
description: Richard Revesz is changing the way the government calculates the cost and benefits of regulation, with far-reaching implications for climate change.
content: This spring the Biden administration proposed or implemented eight major environmental regulations, including the nation’s toughest climate rule, rolling out what experts say are the most ambitious limits on polluting industries by the government in a single season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Beyond the ‘Matrix’ Theory of the Mind
description: To make good on its promise, artificial intelligence needs to deepen human intelligence.
content: Imagine I told you in 1970 that I was going to invent a wondrous tool. This new tool would make it possible for anyone with access — and most of humanity would have access — to quickly communicate and collaborate with anyone else. It would store nearly the sum of human knowledge and thought up to that point, and all of it would be searchable, sortable and portable. Text could be instantly translated from one language to another, news would be immediately available from all over the world, and it would take no longer for a scientist to download a journal paper from 15 years ago than to flip to an entry in the latest issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Catie Edmondson and Luke Broadwater
title: White House and G.O.P. Strike Debt Limit Deal to Avert Default
description: With the government on track to reach its borrowing limit within days, negotiators sealed an agreement to raise the debt ceiling for two years while cutting and capping certain federal programs.
content: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy on Saturday reached an agreement in principle to lift the debt limit for two years while cutting and capping some government spending over the same period, a breakthrough after a marathon set of crisis talks that has brought the nation within days of its first default in history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Sodden Italian Region, Taste of What’s to Come
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 28, 2023.
content: “There is no quick simple solution, no magic wand — that’s why you need to plan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Ian Hacking, Eminent Philosopher of Science and Much Else, Dies at 87
description: Never limited by categories, his free-ranging intellect delved into physics, probability and anthropology, establishing him as a major thinker.
content: Ian Hacking, a Canadian philosopher widely hailed as a giant of modern thought for game-changing contributions to the philosophies of science, probability and mathematics, as well as his widely circulated insights on issues like race and mental health, died on May 10 at a retirement home in Toronto. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: Despite Hochul’s Vow, Her Policies Have Indirectly Aided Husband’s Firm
description: Although Gov. Kathy Hochul says she has taken no role in matters directly affecting Delaware North, the company stood to benefit from her administration’s decisions.
content: The day before she was sworn into office, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York signed an unusual recusal policy forbidding her from using her position to help Delaware North, a global giant in entertainment and hospitality services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pols
title: The Quest for Identity and Independence
description: New books by Irene Muchemi-Ndiritu, Sarah Cypher and Wiz Wharton showcase young women embarking on journeys of discovery around family and self.
content: Irene Muchemi-Ndiritu’s debut novel, LUCKY GIRL (324 pp., Dial Press, paperback, $18), is a coming-of-age story about a privileged but sheltered teenager in Kenya, Soila, who is eager for escape. She wants to leave behind the slums and poverty of Nairobi for the United States, a country she naïvely believes to be without human suffering, but mostly she wants to get away from her mother. Her only living parent, her “yeyo” is a successful businesswoman who is deeply religious and unyielding, sometimes to the point of cruelty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: 2 Are Dead in Suspected Meningitis Outbreak Linked to Surgeries in Mexico
description: More than 200 others could be at risk from a fungal meningitis outbreak that has been traced to two clinics in Matamoros, Mexico, where people traveled for cosmetic surgeries, health officials said.
content: Two people in the United States have died with probable cases of fungal meningitis and more than 200 others are at risk after an outbreak of the infection among patients who had surgery in Matamoros, Mexico, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: With New Voting Bills, Texas Legislature Targets Elections in Democratic Stronghold
description: The bills’ passage was the culmination of a Republican effort to increase oversight of voting in Harris County, which includes Houston.
content: The Texas Legislature gave final approval on Sunday to a new round of voting bills to increase penalties for illegal voting and expand state oversight of local elections specifically in Harris County, which includes Houston, where Democrats have become dominant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘I Could Not Carry Any of My Art’
description: Dozens of Sudanese artists and curators have fled their studios and galleries in the capital, jeopardizing thousands of artworks and imperiling an art scene central to the 2019 revolution.
content: On the morning Sudan’s rival military forces began fighting, Yasir Algrai was in his studio in the center of the country’s capital, prepping for another day of work surrounded by paint colors and canvases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Before Carlos Alcaraz Was Great, He Was Good Enough to Be Lucky
description: Success has many fathers. In Alcaraz’s case, he was born to an actual tennis-playing father, and then the local candy company swooped in to help.
content: Carlos Alcaraz is so good, so young, and wins so often that his success has seemed predetermined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Initial Takeaways From the Spending and Debt Ceiling Deal
description: Details are trickling out about the accord that could avert a default on the national debt. Here’s what to know.
content: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy reached an agreement on Saturday to raise the debt ceiling while imposing new restraints on federal spending. If approved by Congress, it will end a partisan deadlock and avert a potentially devastating national default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Grant
title: Your Most Ambivalent Relationships Are the Most Toxic
description: Science shows that seesaw relationships can be more damaging than those that are purely negative.
content: It’s been two decades, but I still feel jittery when I think of an old boss of mine. One day she nominated me for an award for service to the organization. Then she threatened to fire me for raising a concern about a colleague being mistreated. “If you ever speak up out of turn again,” she said, “I’ll have you fired.” I walked on eggshells until the day she quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Chris Cameron
title: With Debt Limit Deal in Hand, McCarthy and Biden Turn to Task of Selling It
description: With the right and the left up in arms about the agreement in principle reached by the president and the speaker, both sides started to make the case for its quick passage, a tall order in Congress.
content: A day after striking a deal in principle with President Biden to suspend the debt limit, Speaker Kevin McCarthy and his leadership team began an all-out sales pitch on Sunday to rally Republicans behind a compromise that was drawing intense resistance from the hard right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: An Emblem of Globe-Spanning Ambition
description: A new world was born after World War II, and The New York Times was determined to shape it.
content: When the United States entered World War II in 1941, The New York Times was an important regional paper. When the war ended in 1945, The Times was poised to become a global player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Henry Threadgill’s Musical Spring Is Varied and Extreme. Like He Is.
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer has released a memoir, “Easily Slip Into Another World,” and a new album, “The Other One.”
content: Even as a child, Henry Threadgill liked to experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Maternity’s Most Dangerous Time: After New Mothers Come Home
description: Recent research shows that most pregnancy-related deaths occur in the year after a baby is born. The discovery is changing how doctors care for new mothers.
content: Sherri Willis-Prater’s baby boy was 2 months old, and she was about to return to her job at a school cafeteria in Chicago. But as she walked up the short flight of stairs to her kitchen one evening, she nearly collapsed, gasping for breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: ‘Stealth Wealth’ and Bare Feet: How Power Dresses on ‘Succession’
description: The show’s costume designer, Michelle Matland, explained why she always starts “at the bottom.”
content: Followers of the Styles desk’s discussions about the clothes worn on “Succession” (as well as a number of social media accounts) know how obsessively fans have tracked and dissected the characters’ cardigans, caps, shoes, watches and, on occasion, unfortunate handbags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin and Javier C. Hernández
title: Gustavo Dudamel in New York: Selfies, Hugs and Mahler
description: Our photographer followed the maestro when he came to town to conduct Mahler’s Ninth — his first time leading the New York Philharmonic since being named its next music director.
content: The violins were tuning, the woodwinds warming up and the trumpets blaring bits of Mahler. Then the musicians of the New York Philharmonic began to whistle and cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Sophie Park
title: In Provincetown, Mass., a Matchmaker Helps the Desperate Find Housing
description: A mix of extreme conditions has made the remote Cape Cod town’s housing market one of the most harrowing in New England.
content: As soon as he saw the post on Facebook, from a young woman seeking summer housing for her boyfriend, Dan McKeon knew what was going to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Henrik Pryser Libell
title: A Russian Deserter’s Flight to Norway Presents a Fraught Dilemma for His Host
description: Andrei Medvedev fought with Russia’s Wagner mercenaries in Ukraine, then requested asylum in Norway. The authorities there must now weigh his plea against solidarity with Ukraine.
content: Sipping a $12 beer in one of the world’s wealthiest capitals, Andrei Medvedev reflected on the question hanging over him since he left the battlefields of Ukraine: Is he a hero or a war criminal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla M. Williams
title: Who Should We Honor on Memorial Day?
description: The commemoration is intended to remember, honor and salute the nation’s fallen service members. But not all of those we should recognize fit neatly into that definition.
content: In 1866, four women placing spring flowers on the graves of Confederate soldiers at Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Miss., noticed that the nearby graves of Union soldiers were barren. They took it upon themselves to decorate those, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Meet the New Mayor: How a Refugee Won Over a Conservative German Town
description: The election of Ryyan Alshebl, a young man who fled Syria, offers surprising lessons for a Germany wrestling with its multicultural identity after an influx of refugees in 2015.
content: The beer was flowing, the bratwurst were sizzling and the brass band at the village May Day festival led the crowd in ever tipsier renditions of the local drinking song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Tim Keller Showed Me What a Christian Leader Should Be
description: A pastor who truly loved his neighbors, even across deep divides.
content: In my early 20s, I attended an event where Tim Keller, an orthodox, evangelical Presbyterian pastor, was having a public debate with a secular humanist. In the nearly 20 years that have passed since the event, I still recall one moment distinctly. The secular humanist struggled with a point he was making and was unclear, something that happens often enough in public speaking. Keller could have chosen to go in for the kill rhetorically and make his opponent look foolish. Instead, he paused and asked, “Is this what you mean?” Keller then restated the secular argument in a clearer, better way, arguing against his own point of view. The other speaker agreed that was what he had meant, and Keller continued, countering the (now much stronger) point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jassi Pannu and Jacob Swett
title: What if There Was Never a Pandemic Again?
description: Pandemics are not inevitable.
content: Modern humans have existed for over 200,000 years. A mere 500 years ago, daily life was ‌strewn with infectious risk. ‌Eating a meal was a risk, as was drinking a glass of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates and Alex Traub
title: George Maharis, TV Heartthrob of ‘Route 66,’ Is Dead at 94
description: He appeared in Off Broadway roles before starring on CBS as one of two young men who find adventure crossing the country in a Corvette convertible.
content: George Maharis, the ruggedly handsome New York-born stage actor who went on to become a 1960s television heartthrob as a star of the series “Route 66,” died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Chris Christie Scenario
description: Nothing delights the MAGA king more than curb-stomping the weak. Where does the Republican Party go from here?
content: At this point, it seems a little gratuitous to pick at the scab of Gov. Ron DeSantis’s not-so-dazzling presidential campaign opening. Let us just stipulate that when your long-anticipated announcement jump-starts #DeSaster trending on social media, things could have gone better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Right Is All Wrong About Masculinity
description: Shrieking on Twitter is not a masculine virtue.
content: There is a certain irony in discussions of masculinity. The group that is most convinced of a crisis of masculinity, the American right, is also busy emasculating itself before our eyes. It correctly perceives that young men are facing an identity crisis, yet it is modeling precisely the wrong response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Kyiv Repels Its Largest Ever Drone Attack Launched by Russian Forces
description: More than 40 drones were intercepted over Kyiv, where city officials said at least one person had been killed, probably by falling debris.
content: Explosions echoed across Ukraine’s capital for hours before dawn on Sunday as air defense teams raced to combat the largest swarm of Russian attack drones targeting Kyiv since the war began more than 15 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Everton Saved Its Premier League Status. But for How Long?
description: A win on the final day of the season kept Everton in the league and relegated Leicester and Leeds. But those results may be subject to change.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — The announcement rang out around Goodison Park before kickoff, and then again ahead of the second half. In a clear, commanding voice, it informed Everton’s fans that they were not, under any circumstances, to invade the field or throw objects at the players on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: How the Editor of Sunday Routine Spends Her Sundays
description: Hilary Howard, who edits the popular weekly column for The New York Times, is not a fan of brunch. Well, of reading about it.
content: For Hilary Howard, a senior editor on the Metro desk at The New York Times, every day feels like a Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: A U.S. debt-limit deal
description: Also, a reader-made playlist.
content: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy reached an agreement in principle to lift the debt limit for two years, a breakthrough after a marathon of crisis talks that brought the nation within days of its first default in history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: May 28, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 28, 2023.
content: An article last Sunday about the Century 21 department store reopening as Century 21 NYC included an anecdote from a shopper from Staten Island. After publication, The Times learned that the shopper had provided a false name. The passage has been removed from the article.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and J. David Goodman
title: Takeaways From the Impeachment of Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton
description: The extraordinary vote on impeachment exposed rifts among Texas Republicans and set the stage for a contentious showdown in the State Senate.
content: Ken Paxton, the firebrand Republican Texas attorney general, was temporarily thrown out of office on Saturday by House lawmakers — many from his own party — who voted to impeach him over a series of bribery and corruption allegations, including that he had given special treatment to a campaign donor who helped him remodel his house.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Made a New Year’s Resolution to Have a Standing Solo Dinner Date’
description: Savoring a meal alone at the bar, a hat takes a ride on the East Side and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Modi Opens India’s New Parliament Building as Opposition Boycotts
description: The complex is a testament to the prime minister’s power to get things done, but the ceremony also put the nation’s political divisions on display.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday inaugurated a sleek new Parliament complex, part of a more than $2 billion project to revamp India’s decrepit colonial-era center of government in New Delhi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Josh Katz
title: Verstappen Rules in Monaco’s Rain
description: Red Bull’s Max Verstappen successfully defended his lead when deteriorating conditions sent teams scrambling for the right tires and he cruised to his fourth win of the Formula 1 season.
content: The Circuit de Monaco is one of the most iconic stops on Formula 1’s schedule, but it is also one of its most treacherous. A hairpin descent. Walls close enough to kiss. A dark tunnel that ejects drivers into a burst of blinding sunlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Complications After Delivery: What Women Need to Know
description: New mothers are at risk for up to a year, research has shown. But the first six weeks are the most perilous.
content: After a woman gives birth, the baby’s well-being usually becomes the focus of family attention, and the mother’s health often recedes as a priority. Many busy new mothers don’t make it to their postpartum visit with an obstetrician or midwife, even though recent medical guidelines say they should do so within three weeks of the delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: A Way to Play Things
description: Katie Hale and Zachary David Levy’s grid induces oohs and aahs.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Schaff, Linda Qiu, Marisa Schwartz Taylor and Sean Catangui
title: How to Open a National Park for the Summer Season
description: Anticipating a swell of visitors as peak season begins, workers at Bryce Canyon National Park are clearing trails, training rangers and conserving wildlife.
content: Anticipating a swell of visitors as peak season begins, workers at Bryce Canyon National Park are clearing trails, training rangers and conserving wildlife.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Best Memorial Day Desserts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: The Big Number: +20.7%
description: If you’re planning a big cookout on Memorial Day, the Alabama grocer Jimmy Wright recommends chicken. Here’s why.
content: If you’re planning a big cookout on Memorial Day, the Alabama grocer Jimmy Wright recommends chicken. Here’s why.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Best Memorial Day Recipes
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Gas Grills
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Protein Bars Healthy or Just Glorified Candy Bars?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Russia Launches Largest Drone Attack on Kyiv Since War Began
description: Ukrainian officials said that more than 40 drones were intercepted over the capital hours before residents celebrated Kyiv Day to mark the city’s founding. Falling debris may have killed one person.
content: Ukrainian officials said that more than 40 drones were intercepted over the capital hours before residents celebrated Kyiv Day to mark the city’s founding. Falling debris may have killed one person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden and McCarthy Reach Debt Ceiling Agreement
description: The deal capped months of political brinkmanship and a marathon negotiation, though it will still need congressional passage in the coming days to avert a default.
content: The deal capped months of political brinkmanship and a marathon negotiation, though it will still need congressional passage in the coming days to avert a default.
source.name: The New York Times
